{Author's Name} <[[#author-socialcast-profile]]>, {Author's Corporate Title} Many years before software gave us the ability to spin them up at the click of a mouse, a group of artists treated us to the wonders of painstaking photomosaics <[[https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Photographic_mosaic]]>. Taken as a whole, these image fragments form a portrait, while each photo itself held its own story.
Much like those mosaics, the fragments of story in this issue come together as a portrait of change. Labs Designer Michelle Kang writes on hacking a workspace to spur a Labs collaboration. Fred Melo weighs in on bridging real-time and in-memory data with the inspired beta that is Pivotal Gemfire 9.0, and the GSS team introduces a sleek new customer portal.
Somewhat related and for nearly two years running, Inside Pivotal has evolved—small-batch style. The latest iteration brings a cleaner, user-friendly People site <[[https://sites.google.com/a/pivotal.io/inside-pivotal/departments/human-resources]]> and a scaled-up but crisper Asset Library <[[https://sites.google.com/a/pivotal.io/inside-pivotal/asset-library]]>.
Finally, there are no dull moments at Pivotal, so be sure attend or watch tomorrow's Town Hall <[[https://sites.google.com/a/pivotal.io/inside-pivotal/pivotal-town-hall]]> (12:30pm PDT) for company updates on the recent funding round and other big items.
Enjoy. BUSINESS UPDATE

{Author's Name} <[[#author-socialcast-profile]]>, {Author's Corporate Title} Physical space facilitates quality work in digital space. Last month, I flew to Washington DC to work on a project that yielded the perfect opportunity to "hack a space" for optimal collaboration. Given the whiteboarding, brainstorming, and collaboration essential to the start of the project (a classic Discovery & Framing <[[https://blog.pivotal.io/labs/labs/discovery-and-framing-design-studio]]> session), we thought it would be good to redesign the space to enable our work.
Our Washington DC office is comprised of a series of rented rooms from the coworking space WeWork <[[https://www.wework.com/]]>. Our project had its own room, and one of its defining features was the island of standing desks combined in the middle of the room blocking open communication. More chairs and additional shorter tables claimed valuable space next to the walls, and we had to maneuver around these obstacles to reach each other across the room.
In the spirit of Labs, we tried an experiment. Why not move the tall tables to the sides, and move the shorter desks to the middle? We could form a desk in the middle for workshops and impromptu meetings during the collaboration heavy portion of this research phase. If it didn't work out, we could move it back.
Above: Before and after shots featuring teammates Mariesa Dale and Laurel Gray.
The room also had no whiteboards, so we used easel pad paper to serve the same purpose, lining the remaining two walls with the paper and placed our movable whiteboard by the workshop tables. Here is the front of the room, lined with an agenda and brief notes on why we conduct D&Fs, and beautiful blank spaces eagerly waiting to be filled:
With these simple changes the room opened up into an inviting space that set the tone for a Labs engagement—or facilitating shared understanding, shared ownership, and equal voices in conversations. We often take a room arrangement as a given, but arranging the space to meet team needs is crucial for facilitating our best work. Space is fluid, not static. In fact, once we started development on this project, we changed it again.
And guess what? Solving real needs by identifying problems, experimenting with solutions, and continuing to iterate: that's design. MY NAME IS...
